ΙοοΚεμΞΔ a child born with red or flaxen hair would be looked upon as a monster amongst them. The manner of dressing the hair differs in different nations, times, and conditions. The Abipones, previously to their entering colonies‚ shaved their hair like monks, leaving nothing but a circle of hair round the head. But the . women of the Mbaya nation, after shaving the rest of their headS, leave some hairs untouched‚ to grow like the erest of a helmet, from the forehead to the crown. As the savages have neither razors nor scissars, they use a shell sharpened against a stone, or the jaws of the fish palometa‚ for the purpose of shaving. Most of the Abipones in our colonies let their hair grow long, and twist it into a rope like Euro- pean soldiers. The same fashion was adopted by the women, but with this difference‚ that they tie the braid of hair with a little piece of white cotton, as our eountrymen do with blaek.

At chureh, and in mournings for the dead, they scatter their hair about their shoulders. The Guarany Indians, on the contrary, whilst they live in the woods, without the knowledge of religion, let their hair hang down their backs : now that they have embraced Christianity, and entered various colonies, they crop it like priests.
